Topics.Specification_section: International Relations: the changing international order 1918–1975
Topics.Topic_name: International Relations: the changing international order 1918–1975

Sub_topics.description: Know the terms/aims and significance of the Versailles Peace Settlement and how it shaped international relations after 1918 (as part of the narrative of international relations 1918–1975).

Know the role, actions and significance of the League of Nations in the 1920s; be able to explain successes and failures of internationalist approaches in this period and how these influenced later international relations.
Know what the Dawes Plan (1924) was and how it aimed to address post-war economic/political tensions; explain its significance for international co-operation in the 1920s.
Know the Locarno agreements (1925): what was agreed and why; explain how Locarno contributed to international co-operation (and its limits) in the 1920s.
Know the aims and nature of the Kellogg–Briand Pact (1928) and why it mattered; evaluate its effectiveness/limitations in maintaining peace.
Know what the Young Plan (1929) proposed and why; explain its significance for reparations and international relations in the late 1920s.
Know key attempts at disarmament in the interwar period; explain why disarmament was pursued and why it was difficult to achieve, linking to the overall narrative of retreat from co-operation.
Know the impact of the worldwide economic depression on international relations and how it contributed to a retreat to nationalism in the 1930s.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: League of Nations failures in the 1930s
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why the League of Nations failed in the 1930s and the consequences for international relations and security in Europe.
Know the policy of Appeasement in the 1930s: what it involved and why it was pursued; explain how it related to rising tension in Europe and contributed to the outbreak of war in 1939.
Know the key developments leading to the outbreak of war in 1939 and how these reflected the collapse of collective security and international agreements.
Know the main decisions/issues at Yalta and Potsdam (1945) and explain how these contributed to the changing international order after 1945 and rising Cold War tensions in Europe.
Know the key actions taken by the USSR in Eastern Europe 1945–1948 and explain their consequences for international relations and for relations with the USA and its allies.
Know how and why Germany was divided after 1945 and explain the consequences for European international relations and the development of Cold War blocs.
Know the Truman Doctrine: aims, methods and significance; explain how it represented a shift in US policy and contributed to Cold War tensions.
Know the Marshall Plan: aims and impact; explain how it affected Europe and contributed to the deepening Cold War divide.
Know the causes, events and consequences of the Berlin Blockade and Airlift; explain its significance for Cold War relations and Germany’s division.
Know why NATO was formed and its role/significance within the Cold War alliance system.
Know why the Warsaw Pact was formed and its role/significance within the Cold War alliance system; relate to NATO as opposing blocs.
Know why the Berlin Wall was built in 1961 and explain its effects on international relations and Cold War tensions in Europe.
Know the causes, key events and outcomes of the Cuban Missile Crisis (1962) and explain why it was a major Cold War confrontation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins of US involvement in Vietnam (1954–65)
Sub_topics.description: Know the origins of US involvement in Vietnam from 1954 to 1965 and how Cold War thinking/containment contributed to escalation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: US tactics in Vietnam and consequences
Sub_topics.description: Know key US tactics used in the Vietnam War and explain their military, political and social consequences.
Know key Vietcong tactics used in the Vietnam War and explain their consequences for the course of the war and US strategy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: US withdrawal from Vietnam and US opposition
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why the USA withdrew from Vietnam, including the role and significance of opposition in the USA to the war.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of Vietnam War and impact on international relations
Sub_topics.description: Know the end of the Vietnam War and explain its impact on international relations and the wider Cold War context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpretations of appeasement: impact of WWII
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why the Second World War influenced differing interpretations of appeasement (e.g., immediate post-war judgements) and be able to explain links between context and interpretation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpretations of appeasement: impact of Cold War
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why the Cold War context affected interpretations of appeasement and how historians’ perspectives changed with new political circumstances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpretations of appeasement: new evidence c.1990+
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why new sources of evidence from c.1990 onwards contributed to changing interpretations of appeasement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpretations of Cold War responsibility: US/USSR internal culture & politics
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why the internal culture and politics of the USSR and USA have been used to argue differing responsibility for the Cold War; explain how historians’ choices of emphasis shape interpretations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpretations of Cold War responsibility: Vietnam War influence
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why the Vietnam War influenced interpretations of responsibility for the Cold War (e.g., views of US motives/policy) and how later events shape historical judgement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpretations of Cold War responsibility: new evidence c.1990+
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why new sources of evidence from c.1990 onwards contributed to changing interpretations of responsibility for the Cold War.

Topics.Specification_section: China 1950–1981: The People and the State (J410/01)
Topics.Topic_name: China 1950–1981: The People and the State (J410/01)

Sub_topics.description: Know early Communist purges against opposition in the 1950s and how they operated in cities, countryside and regions; explain aims and impacts on different groups of people.
Know the intentions and impact of the Hundred Flowers campaign; explain why it occurred and its consequences for opposition and the relationship between people and state.
Know Communist social policies under Mao and how these differed from Chinese traditionalism; explain impacts on society and everyday life.
Know Mao-era policies towards women and evaluate impacts on women’s roles, rights and everyday experiences.
Know Mao-era policies towards young people and evaluate impacts on youth roles, expectations and experiences.
Know Mao-era education policies and evaluate their purposes and impacts on different groups (including social mobility and ideological control).
Know early land reform policies and explain aims, implementation and impact on rural society and class groups.
Know collectivisation policies and evaluate their impact on peasants, production, and state control over the countryside.
Know the First Five Year Plan as industrial policy: aims, methods and effects on workers, cities and the economy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Leap Forward: aims and policies
Sub_topics.description: Know the aims and key policies of the Great Leap Forward and how it was intended to transform agriculture/industry and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Leap Forward: effects on society
Sub_topics.description: Know the effects of the Great Leap Forward across Chinese society; explain who was affected and how (social classes, regions, rural/urban).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Leap Forward: reasons for failure
Sub_topics.description: Know the reasons for the failure of the Great Leap Forward, including policy design/implementation issues and consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dazhai Commune (case study: Mao economic policies)
Sub_topics.description: Use Dazhai Commune as a case study to illustrate Mao’s economic policies in practice; know key features and explain what it shows about policy aims, propaganda and lived experience.
Know reasons for the Cultural Revolution and how political/ideological aims related to control of society and the Party.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cultural Revolution: impact on intellectuals and students
Sub_topics.description: Know the impact of the Cultural Revolution on the people, including intellectuals and students; explain patterns of persecution, disruption and social change.
Know the role of the Red Guards in the Cultural Revolution and explain their actions and effects on society and state power.
Know the impact of Communism in Tibet in this period and what it reveals about state policy, repression and minority regions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Communist propaganda and Mao personality cult (impact)
Sub_topics.description: Know the nature of Communist propaganda and its impact, including Mao’s personality cult; explain how propaganda shaped beliefs/behaviour and support/opposition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dazhai (case study: Party repression during Cultural Revolution)
Sub_topics.description: Use Dazhai community as a case study of Communist Party repression during/linked to the Cultural Revolution; know examples of control/coercion and explain consequences for people.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gang of Four and repression after 1976
Sub_topics.description: Know attitudes to opposition and its repression after 1976, including the Gang of Four; explain what this indicates about power struggles and control after Mao’s death.
Know the ‘Democracy Wall’ movement and state repression; explain how it shows limits of reform and treatment of dissent.
Know changes in economic policy under Deng and their impact; explain how reforms altered people’s lives, opportunities and inequalities.
Know the Four Modernisations: what they were intended to modernise and why; explain their significance within Deng’s reforms.
Know the nature of Communist propaganda and its impact in the Deng era; explain continuities/changes from Mao-era propaganda and purposes in maintaining authority.
Know social changes under Deng affecting the role of women; explain how reforms influenced gender roles, work and family life.
Know changes in education under Deng and their impact on society, opportunity and state priorities.
Know the One Child policy: aims, implementation and social impact; explain consequences for families, gender balance and state-society relations.

Topics.Specification_section: Germany 1925–1955: The People and the State (J410/02)
Topics.Topic_name: Germany 1925–1955: The People and the State (J410/02)

Sub_topics.description: Know strengths and weaknesses of the Weimar Republic 1925–1928 and how these affected political stability and support for parties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi policies in the 1920s and position in 1928
Sub_topics.description: Know Nazi policies in the 1920s and the party’s position in 1928; explain why support was limited before the Depression.
Know the impact of the Great Depression on different groups in Germany; explain how economic hardship translated into political change and rising extremism.
Know the political, social and economic crisis of 1929–1933 and how it undermined Weimar democracy and created conditions for Nazi rise.
Know reasons for rising support for the Nazis 1929–1933 (including propaganda, promises, fear of communism, appeal to different social groups).
Know the Reichstag Fire and how it was used to increase Nazi power; explain consequences for civil liberties and opposition.
Know how and why the Weimar constitution was suspended and what this meant for rights and political opposition.
Know the Enabling Act: what it allowed and why it was crucial for Nazi dictatorship; explain impact on democratic institutions.
Know the elections of March 1933 and how they contributed to Nazi consolidation of power.
Know how the Nazis took over or collaborated with key institutions (especially the army) and why this mattered for consolidating rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elimination of opposition: trade unions, parties, SA
Sub_topics.description: Know how opposition was eliminated 1933–34, including trade unions, opposition parties and the SA; explain methods and significance for dictatorship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi terror state: SA, SS, Gestapo, SD, courts, police
Sub_topics.description: Know elements of the Nazi terror state (SA, SS, Gestapo, SD, courts and police) and how terror enforced conformity and suppressed opposition.
Know how the Nazis used culture and propaganda; explain aims, methods and effects on attitudes and behaviour.
Know reasons for Hitler’s personal popularity and how it helped sustain the regime; consider relationship between popularity, propaganda and policy outcomes.
Know Nazi attempts to create a National Community (Volksgemeinschaft): aims, policies and exclusions; explain intended social unity and control.
Know Nazi economic policies and their effects on different sections of German society (identify winners and losers); link to support/opposition and everyday life.
Know Nazi social policies on women (roles, employment, family, ideology) and evaluate impacts and contradictions.
Know Nazi social policies on youth (education, youth movements, indoctrination) and evaluate impacts on young people and society.
Know reasons for the lack of effective opposition to the Nazi regime 1933–1939 (terror, propaganda, conformity, divisions).
Know persecution of Jews: methods, escalation and impacts on Jewish people and wider society.
Know persecution of Roma: policies, treatment and significance within Nazi racial ideology.
Know persecution of Jehovah’s Witnesses and how it reflected Nazi intolerance and control.
Know persecution of homosexuals and how it reflected Nazi social/racial policies and repression.
Know Nazi eugenics policies (e.g., sterilisation, ‘racial hygiene’) and their impacts; explain ideological rationale and consequences for victims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Initial reaction to outbreak of war (1939)
Sub_topics.description: Know the initial German reaction to the outbreak of war in 1939 and what this suggests about support, expectations and propaganda.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing fortunes in war: initial gains and colonisation in the East
Sub_topics.description: Know Germany’s changing fortunes in the war, including initial gains and colonisation in the East; explain impacts on policy and people.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of war: bombing and home front
Sub_topics.description: Know the growing impact of war on Germany, including bombing; explain effects on civilians, morale and state control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extent of support for war effort
Sub_topics.description: Know and evaluate the extent of German support for the war effort over time, considering coercion, propaganda and lived experience.
Know forms of opposition during the war and explain their motives, extent and significance.
Know how racial persecution escalated to the Holocaust; explain key stages/decisions and impacts on victims and German society/state.
Know the consequences of defeat and occupation for Germany and German people; explain immediate changes in governance and daily life.
Know Allied policy of de-Nazification: methods used and their impact; evaluate effectiveness and consequences for different groups.
Know the differing experiences of people in East and West Germany 1945–1955 and how occupation and emerging Cold War divisions shaped society and politics.

Topics.Specification_section: South Africa 1960–1994: The People and the State (J410/05)
Topics.Topic_name: South Africa 1960–1994: The People and the State (J410/05)

Sub_topics.description: Know the consolidation of Apartheid through ‘Separate Development’ and the establishment of the Bantustans; explain aims and impacts on different communities.
Know the nature and extent of support for Apartheid and why some groups/institutions supported the regime.
Know methods used by the government to maintain the Apartheid regime (laws, policing, censorship, repression) and explain impacts on people and opposition.
Know events of the Sharpeville Massacre and explain its immediate and longer-term impact on resistance, repression and international opinion.
Know reasons for, methods of and impact of ANC resistance to Apartheid in the 1960s and beyond; link to mass protest and armed struggle.
Know the Freedom Charter and explain its continuing impact on anti-Apartheid aims, messaging and legitimacy.
Know the creation, methods and significance of Umkhonto we Sizwe as part of resistance to Apartheid.
Know Poqo: aims, methods and significance within the wider resistance movement.
Know the Rivonia Trial (1964) and explain its consequences for leadership (e.g., imprisonment), opposition strategies and the regime.
Know the Black Consciousness Movement and how it contributed to resistance in the 1970s; explain its ideas and significance.
Know SASO (South African Students’ Organisation): role, activities and significance in developing resistance.
Know the role of women’s groups in resistance during the 1970s and how gender influenced participation and repression.
Know the role of trade unions in resistance, including the Durban workers’ strike (1973); explain impacts on the regime and political mobilisation.
Know causes, events and consequences of the Soweto students’ uprising (1976); explain why it was a turning point in resistance and repression.
Know the role and significance of the ANC in exile and how it sustained resistance and international pressure.
Know the international Anti-Apartheid Movement and how it applied pressure (boycotts, lobbying, awareness); explain significance for the regime.
Know how the Apartheid regime responded to growing resistance in the 1970s (repression, reform attempts, policing) and assess impacts.
Know the impact of sanctions on South Africa in the 1980s and how economic/international pressure contributed to regime crisis.
Know the role and significance of the United Democratic Front (UDF) in mass resistance and political mobilisation.
Know the growth and impact of mass resistance in the 1980s and how it challenged the Apartheid state and reshaped political possibilities.
Know the growth of Inkatha, the development of ‘civil war’/political violence and the impact on Black communities; explain how conflict affected negotiations and society.
Know reasons for and forms of opposition to the 1983 constitution and why it failed to resolve legitimacy crisis.
Know the State of Emergency 1985–1990: measures used and consequences for civil rights, resistance and international opinion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divisions in National Party and failure of ‘total strategy’
Sub_topics.description: Know divisions within the National Party government and reasons for the failure of ‘total strategy’; explain how this weakened the regime.
Know the impact of the defeat at Cuito Cuanavale and how it affected regional politics, military confidence and pressure on the Apartheid regime.
Know the role of FW de Klerk in the process of ending Apartheid; explain motives, actions and significance.
Know the role of Ramaphosa in negotiations and political change; explain significance within the transition.
Know the role of Nelson Mandela in resistance and transition to democracy; explain significance of leadership, negotiations and reconciliation politics.
Know the key features of negotiations between the government and the ANC, including obstacles and compromises; explain why negotiations succeeded.
Know the unbanning of the ANC, Pan African Congress and South African Communist Party; explain significance for political opening and transition.
Know the first free elections in 1994 and explain why they marked a decisive stage in the collapse of Apartheid and establishment of new state-society relations.

Topics.Specification_section: The USA 1919–1948: The People and the State (J410/06)
Topics.Topic_name: The USA 1919–1948: The People and the State (J410/06)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Republican policies and ideology in the 1920s
Sub_topics.description: Know Republican party policies and ideology in the 1920s and how they shaped government action and economic/social outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prosperity: industries/social groups that benefited or missed out
Sub_topics.description: Know which areas of industry and which social groups did and did not experience prosperity in the ‘Roaring Twenties’; explain reasons for uneven prosperity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Women’s rights movements and Sheppard–Towner Act
Sub_topics.description: Know the US government and women in the 1920s, including women’s rights movements and the Sheppard–Towner Act; explain significance for women’s health/welfare and politics.
Know causes and aims of prohibition; explain why it was introduced and what it intended to achieve.
Know how prohibition was implemented and why it failed; explain consequences for crime, politics and society.
Know the Jim Crow Laws and how they enforced segregation and discrimination; explain effects on African Americans and society.
Know the Ku Klux Klan in the 1920s: beliefs, methods and influence; explain role in prejudice and intimidation.
Know the Palmer Raids as part of the Red Scare; explain causes, actions and consequences for civil liberties and politics.
Know the Sacco and Vanzetti case and why it became significant; explain what it reveals about prejudice, justice and political fear.
Know restrictions on immigration throughout the 1920s; explain reasons (nativism, economic fears, racism, political ideology) and impacts.
Know how the NAACP attempted to combat prejudice/discrimination in this period; explain strategies and limitations.
Know how the UNIA attempted to combat prejudice/discrimination; explain aims, appeal and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Depression: economic and social effects and government response
Sub_topics.description: Know the economic and social effects of the Great Depression and evaluate the government response leading up to the New Deal.
Know the main issues and significance of the 1932 presidential election campaigns and why Roosevelt won.
Know Roosevelt’s First New Deal and the Hundred Days: aims, urgency and key measures; explain how it changed the role of the federal government.
Know the Agricultural Adjustment Administration (AAA): purpose, methods and impact on farmers and food production/prices.
Know the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC): purpose and impact on unemployment, environment projects and young men.
Know the Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA): purpose and impact on relief for the unemployed/poor.
Know the National Recovery Administration (NRA): purpose, codes and impact; explain controversies/limitations.
Know the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA): aims and impact on regional development, electricity, jobs and planning.
Know the Works Progress Administration (WPA): purpose and impact on employment and infrastructure/culture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Second New Deal: Social Security Act
Sub_topics.description: Know the Social Security Act: aims, provisions and significance for welfare and state responsibility.
Know the Wagner Act: aims and significance for trade unions and workers’ rights.
Know the Resettlement Administration: aims and impact (including support for poor farmers/migrants).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Second New Deal: Farm Security Administration
Sub_topics.description: Know the Farm Security Administration (FSA): aims and impact on rural poverty and farming communities.
Know reactions to the New Deal(s) from different groups and institutions; explain reasons for support and opposition.
Know and evaluate the impact of the New Deal(s) on the economy, society and the role of government; consider limitations and long-term significance.
Know wartime propaganda campaigns in WWII and how they mobilised the population; explain effects on attitudes and participation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mobilisation for war: war production and effects
Sub_topics.description: Know the expansion of war production and its effects (including employment and industrial change) and how it contributed to ending the Depression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Increased government and presidential powers (wages/prices control)
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why government and presidential powers increased during WWII, including control of wages and prices; explain significance for state-society relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public response to US involvement in WWII
Sub_topics.description: Know the response of the US population to involvement in WWII; explain how support, sacrifice and dissent were managed.
Know the social impact of the war including rationing and taxes on luxuries; explain effects on everyday life and morale.
Know wartime social impacts including housing shortages and an increase in divorce; explain causes and significance.
Know women’s role in the WWII war effort and how it affected gender roles, employment and post-war expectations.
Know Japanese internment during WWII: reasons, implementation and impact; evaluate civil liberties and racism in wartime.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War as foundation for Civil Rights movement
Sub_topics.description: Know how WWII acted as a foundation for the Civil Rights movement; explain mechanisms (military service, labour demand, ideology) and resulting pressures for change.
Know the Detroit Race Riots (1943): causes, events and significance for race relations and wartime tensions.
Know segregation within the US military during WWII and its effects on African Americans and civil rights pressures.
Know Executive Order 8802: why it was issued and its significance for employment discrimination and civil rights.
Know the desegregation of US troops in 1948 and explain why it was significant for civil rights and state action.

Topics.Specification_section: The USA 1945–1974: The People and the State (J410/07)
Topics.Topic_name: The USA 1945–1974: The People and the State (J410/07)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government concerns about Communism and media campaigns
Sub_topics.description: Know post-war concerns about Communism in the USA and responses, including media campaigns promoting American values and institutions; explain aims and effects on society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Late 1940s Red Scare: J. Edgar Hoover
Sub_topics.description: Know the role of J. Edgar Hoover in the late 1940s Red Scare; explain methods and impact on politics and civil liberties.
Know the Rosenberg case and why it mattered in the Red Scare context; explain impact on fear of espionage and public opinion.
Know reactions to the Red Scare (support, criticism, fear, resistance) and explain how it affected society and politics.
Know the nature of McCarthyism and reasons for its support and opposition; explain consequences for individuals and political culture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Jim Crow and African American inequality (1945–54)
Sub_topics.description: Know the position of African Americans 1945–1954: Jim Crow Laws, access to education, voting rights and employment inequality; explain how these conditions shaped civil rights activism.
Know Brown v. Board of Education (1954): decision and significance; explain how it challenged segregation and triggered resistance/support.
Know the Montgomery Bus Boycott (1956): causes, methods, outcomes and significance for mass protest and leadership.
Know the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr. in civil rights campaigns; explain strategies (non-violence, mass mobilisation) and significance.
Know the role of SNCC in civil rights campaigns; explain tactics, achievements and evolution.
Know the role of SCLC in civil rights campaigns; explain strategies and significance in organising protest.
Know the role of the NAACP in civil rights campaigns 1954–1964; explain legal and organisational strategies and impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to civil rights: illegal organisations
Sub_topics.description: Know forms of opposition to the civil rights movement, including illegal organisations; explain motives and impacts on activists and progress.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to civil rights: police and state authorities
Sub_topics.description: Know the role of police and state authorities in opposing/limiting civil rights campaigns; explain how state power was used and its consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Supreme Court contribution to civil rights
Sub_topics.description: Know how the Supreme Court contributed to improving civil rights and how legal decisions interacted with activism and resistance.
Know the role of Kennedy in civil rights campaigns; explain actions/limitations and political context.
Know the role of Johnson in civil rights campaigns; explain political strategy and significance for legislation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil Rights Act (1964): reasons and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for and impact of the Civil Rights Act (1964); explain what changed legally and what remained contested.
Know Malcolm X’s role and impact as a leader of African American radical movements; explain ideas and influence on civil rights direction.
Know the development and impact of Black Power; explain why it emerged and how it changed civil rights activism and public response.
Know the impact of civil rights campaigns for Native Americans; explain aims, methods and significance in the wider context of dissent.
Know the impact of civil rights campaigns for Chicanos; explain aims, methods and significance in the wider context of dissent.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Betty Friedan and feminist movement development
Sub_topics.description: Know the development of feminist movements including the role of Betty Friedan; explain why feminism grew and its key ideas.
Know the National Organization for Women (NOW): aims, campaigns and significance for women’s rights.
Know the Status Commission (1963) and its significance for government engagement with women’s rights.
Know the Equal Pay Act: aims and impact; evaluate effectiveness and limitations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using Civil Rights Act for women’s rights
Sub_topics.description: Know how the Civil Rights Act was used to advance women’s rights; explain legal strategies and outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Supreme Court ruling on equal rights (1972)
Sub_topics.description: Know the 1972 Supreme Court ruling on equal rights referenced in the specification and explain its significance for gender equality.
Know the Stonewall riots (1969): causes and significance; explain how they contributed to LGBTQ+ activism and dissent.
Know anti-Vietnam War protests: causes, nature and impact on politics and society; explain how dissent challenged government policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Campaigns to improve welfare of the poor
Sub_topics.description: Know campaigns to improve welfare of the poor in this period and how they linked to broader political, economic and social divisions.
Know Johnson’s ‘Great Society’: aims and significance; explain how it sought to address poverty/inequality and how it related to dissent and division.
Know Nixon’s pledges on welfare and explain their significance within the politics of division and government response to dissent.

Topics.Specification_section: Migration to Britain c.1000 to c.2010 (J410/08)
Topics.Topic_name: Migration to Britain c.1000 to c.2010 (J410/08)

Sub_topics.description: Know evidence for and nature of population diversity in England before 1066; explain what this shows about early migration and multicultural presence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of the Norman Conquest on migration/diversity
Sub_topics.description: Know how the Norman Conquest changed patterns of migration, settlement and power in England; explain consequences for society and governance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resistance to Normans in William’s reign
Sub_topics.description: Know forms of resistance to the Normans in William’s reign and how conquest/migration of elites affected society and control.
Know the first arrival of Jews in England in/after 1066, including reasons for arrival and early roles/communities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treatment and experiences of Jews to 1290
Sub_topics.description: Know treatment and experiences of Jews in England up to 1290 (including persecution, restrictions, violence); explain causes and consequences.
Know the expulsion of Jews in 1290: reasons, process and significance for English society and state policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resident ‘aliens’ in the Middle Ages: lives and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know the lives and impact of resident ‘aliens’ in medieval England; explain occupations, economic/cultural contributions and community life.
Know how authorities treated immigrants/‘aliens’ in the Middle Ages (legal status, taxation, controls) and explain motivations.
Know how the population generally treated immigrants/‘aliens’ in the Middle Ages; explain examples of acceptance, tension and prejudice.
Know the extent to which medieval immigrants integrated; explain factors affecting assimilation (work, language, religion, law, community).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Africans in 16th-century England: reasons for arrival
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for Africans’ arrival in sixteenth-century England (trade, service, travel) and the contexts that enabled migration.
Know experiences of Africans in sixteenth-century England; explain social status, work, community and prejudice/acceptance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: East India Company foundation and migration links
Sub_topics.description: Know the foundation of the East India Company and how it connected Britain to migration flows from the Indian subcontinent.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lascars and Asian merchant seamen: arrival and lives
Sub_topics.description: Know arrivals of Lascars and other Asian merchant seamen: how they arrived and their lives in England (work, living conditions, settlement).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Child servants and ayahs from the Indian subcontinent
Sub_topics.description: Know migration of child servants and ayahs from the Indian subcontinent: routes, roles and lived experiences in England.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Royal African Company, enslaved Africans trade and community growth
Sub_topics.description: Know the growth of African communities in Britain, including reasons linked to the Royal African Company and the trade in enslaved Africans; explain how empire shaped migration and settlement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Loss of American colonies and migration patterns
Sub_topics.description: Know how loss of the American colonies affected migration patterns and Britain’s relationship with the wider world; explain consequences for people moving to/from Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Expansion of British Empire and migration
Sub_topics.description: Know how expansion of the British Empire influenced migration to Britain (and from Britain); explain connections between imperial power, labour and movement of people.
Know the readmission of Jews in 1656 and their experiences afterward; explain changes from medieval period and factors shaping integration and prejudice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Protestant refugees from 1670s: reasons for emigrating
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for arrival of Protestant refugees from the 1670s (e.g., persecution/war/economic); explain push-pull factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Huguenots and Palatines: reception and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know reception and impact of Huguenots and Palatines in Britain; explain economic/cultural contributions and community relations.
Know the extent of assimilation of Huguenots and Palatines and factors that enabled/limited assimilation over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industrial Revolution: Irish and Scottish migration to England
Sub_topics.description: Know how the Industrial Revolution affected migration, including Irish and Scottish migrants to England; explain reasons and impacts on towns, work and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migrants’ impact on Abolition movement and Chartists
Sub_topics.description: Know the impact of migrants on political movements including the Abolition movement and the Chartists; explain how migrant communities influenced activism and ideas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eastern European Jewish immigrants: experiences and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know experiences and impact of Eastern European Jewish immigrants; explain reasons for migration, settlement patterns, prejudice and contributions.
Know the process of naturalisation and denization and what these legal statuses meant for immigrants; explain how state policy shaped identity and rights.
Know government legislation on immigration and nationality including the Naturalisation Act (1870): purpose and impact on citizenship and belonging.
Know the continued growth of diverse port communities in the early twentieth century; explain causes (trade, empire, labour) and local impacts.
Know reasons for and impact of the Aliens Act (1905); explain how and why the state attempted to control immigration and consequences for migrants.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Status of Aliens Act (1914): reasons and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for and impact of the Status of Aliens Act (1914); explain wartime security and nationality issues shaping migration policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: British Nationality Act (1948): reasons and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for and impact of the British Nationality Act (1948); explain how it affected citizenship, empire/Commonwealth links and migration rights.
Know the arrival of Jewish refugees in the 1930s: reasons for fleeing and routes to Britain; explain state and public responses.
Know different attitudes towards Jews in Britain in the 1930s (support, antisemitism, politics) and how these shaped migrants’ experiences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migrant experiences in the World Wars
Sub_topics.description: Know experiences of migrants and their descendants during the two world wars; explain how war affected belonging, prejudice, work and state policy.
Know the experience of Poles who settled in Britain after the Second World War; explain reasons for settlement and integration challenges.
Know varied reasons for Commonwealth migration after WWII (labour needs, citizenship, push factors); explain diversity of migrant origins and motives.
Know the impact of Commonwealth immigration on Britain (economic, social, cultural, political) and how it reshaped communities and identities.
Know experiences of Commonwealth immigrants (housing, employment, discrimination, community organisation) and forms of resistance and resilience.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Debate over immigration: political racism and antiracism
Sub_topics.description: Know the debate over immigration after WWII including political racism and antiracism; explain key arguments, actors and consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Race relations legislation and immigration controls (impact)
Sub_topics.description: Know the impact of race relations legislation and immigration controls on migrants and society; explain how law both restricted entry and addressed discrimination.
Know the Commonwealth Immigrants Act (1962): why introduced and its impact on migration patterns, families and public debate.
Know the British Nationality Act (1981): reasons and impact on citizenship, belonging and immigration from former empire/Commonwealth.
Know immigration as a political issue c.1990–c.2010, including debates over a ‘multi-cultural society’; explain competing ideas of identity, cohesion and policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Political refugees and asylum seekers: attitudes and treatment
Sub_topics.description: Know attitudes towards and treatment of political refugees and asylum seekers c.1990–c.2010; explain causes of controversy and policy responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: EU open borders and issues raised
Sub_topics.description: Know issues raised by EU ‘open borders’ in c.1990–c.2010 debates; explain how freedom of movement influenced migration, labour and politics.

Topics.Specification_section: Power: Monarchy and Democracy in Britain c.1000 to 2014 (J410/09)
Topics.Topic_name: Power: Monarchy and Democracy in Britain c.1000 to 2014 (J410/09)

Sub_topics.description: Know the basis of Anglo-Saxon kingship c.1000–1066 (sources of legitimacy, expectations) and how kingship was understood in this period.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Power and responsibilities of Anglo-Saxon kings
Sub_topics.description: Know the power and responsibilities of Anglo-Saxon kings (governance, law, military, taxation) and limits on royal authority.
Know relations between kings and thegns in Anglo-Saxon England and how this shaped power-sharing and stability.
Know different claims to the throne in 1066 and how competing claims led to the Norman invasion and transfer of power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Establishment of Norman monarchy and transfer of power
Sub_topics.description: Know how the Norman monarchy was established and how power transferred from Saxons to Normans at all levels of society; explain mechanisms of control (landholding, castles, administration).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monarch vs barons: extent of power by 1087
Sub_topics.description: Know the extent of the power of the monarch and the barons by 1087 and how feudal relationships shaped authority.
Know John’s ascension and early revolts against his rule; explain causes and significance for royal authority and baronial power.
Know John and Magna Carta: why it was agreed, key principles and significance for limits on monarchy and later constitutional development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Emergence of Parliament under Henry III and Edward I
Sub_topics.description: Know the emergence of Parliament in the reigns of Henry III and Edward I and why it developed (taxation, consultation, conflict).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Simon de Montfort: role and importance
Sub_topics.description: Know the role and importance of Simon de Montfort in the development of Parliament and challenges to royal authority.
Know the deposition of Richard II in 1399 and what it reveals about claims to power, legitimacy and elite politics.
Know the Wars of the Roses as struggles over power and legitimacy; explain consequences for monarchy and governance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Growth of royal power under Henry VIII
Sub_topics.description: Know Tudor government and the growth of royal power under Henry VIII; explain methods of maintaining power and the role of institutions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Role of Parliament under Henry VIII and Elizabeth I
Sub_topics.description: Know the role of Parliament under Henry VIII and Elizabeth I and how monarch-Parliament relations affected power and policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charles I’s Personal Rule (as thematic content)
Sub_topics.description: Know Charles I’s personal rule 1629–1640 within the long-term story of monarchy and Parliament; explain why it happened and why it contributed to conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil Wars and abolition of monarchy
Sub_topics.description: Know the Civil Wars and abolition of the monarchy; explain how power changed hands and the significance for constitutional development.
Know the Restoration of the monarchy in 1660 and why it occurred; explain consequences for monarchy-Parliament relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: James II’s rule and reasons for 1688 Revolution
Sub_topics.description: Know James II’s rule and reasons for the Glorious Revolution (1688); explain political and religious causes and consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bill of Rights and legacy of Glorious Revolution
Sub_topics.description: Know the legacy of the Glorious Revolution including the Bill of Rights; explain how it limited monarchy and strengthened Parliament.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Parliament under William III and Anne
Sub_topics.description: Know development of Parliament under William III and Anne; explain how parliamentary power and governance practices evolved.
Know the emergence of political parties and explain why parties developed and how they changed power structures.
Know development of a Parliamentary monarchy during the 1700s; explain change/continuity in power distribution and political culture.
Know reasons for dissatisfaction with the electoral system by the early 1800s and how this motivated reform movements.
Know reasons for and impacts of the Parliamentary Reform Act of 1832; explain how it changed representation and political participation.
Know reasons for and impacts of the Parliamentary Reform Act of 1867; explain changes to franchise and politics.
Know reasons for and impacts of the Parliamentary Reform Act of 1884; explain how it further extended the vote and altered political dynamics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trade unions and Labour Party: rise and effectiveness
Sub_topics.description: Know the rise and effectiveness of mass trade unions and the Labour Party 1880s–1914; explain how they challenged existing power and represented new groups.
Know the struggle for the vote for women and reasons why it was won for some women in 1918; include methods, opposition, wartime context and political calculations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government control in the World Wars
Sub_topics.description: Know government control in the world wars and how wartime expanded state power; explain implications for democracy and citizens’ lives.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Increased role of the state after 1945
Sub_topics.description: Know the increased role of the state from 1945 to c.1980; explain key ways government involvement expanded and impacts on society and politics.
Know the Miners’ Strike 1984–1985 as a challenge to Parliament/government; explain causes, events and significance for power relations.
Know CND and Greenpeace as forms of challenge to Parliament/government; explain methods of activism and influence on policy debate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prime ministerial power under Thatcher and Blair
Sub_topics.description: Know prime ministerial power under Thatcher and Blair; explain how leadership style, media, party control and institutions affected executive power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Devolution of power to UK regions
Sub_topics.description: Know the devolution of power to regions of the UK and explain reasons and consequences for governance and democracy.
Know the challenges of coalition government and explain how coalition arrangements can affect power, accountability and policy-making.

Topics.Specification_section: War and British Society c.790 to c.2010 (J410/10)
Topics.Topic_name: War and British Society c.790 to c.2010 (J410/10)

Sub_topics.description: Know the impact of Viking raids on Anglo-Saxon England 790–1066; explain effects on communities, politics, economy and security.
Know responses to Viking raids; explain defensive strategies, political changes and societal adaptation.
Know forms of English resistance to the Norman Conquest and explain why resistance occurred and why it was overcome.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Establishment of Norman control under William I
Sub_topics.description: Know how Norman control was established under William I and explain how conquest changed governance and society.
Know the establishment of the feudal system after the Norman Conquest and explain how it shaped military service, landholding and social relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of Norman changes on different social levels
Sub_topics.description: Know the extent of the impact of Norman changes on different levels of society; explain who gained/lost and how war/conquest reshaped life.
Know the feudal relationship between monarchs and barons c.1100–1215 and how obligations and expectations could create stability or conflict.
Know breakdowns in the monarch-baron relationship under Stephen 1135–1154; explain causes and consequences for war and society.
Know breakdowns in the monarch-baron relationship under John 1214–1216; explain causes and how conflict related to war, finance and governance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing nature of war and effects (medieval)
Sub_topics.description: Know the changing nature of war in medieval society c.1290–c.1450 and its effects; include technology/tactics and impacts on populations.
Know development and adaptation of feudal service in this period and how military obligations changed; link to social and political impacts.
Know the financial cost of war in medieval society and how taxation/finance affected government-society relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact on populations where armies fought/stationed
Sub_topics.description: Know the impact of war on populations where armies fought or were stationed; explain experiences of civilians and local economies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elizabeth’s wars with Spain: impact on monarch prestige and Parliament relations
Sub_topics.description: Know Elizabeth I’s wars with Spain in Europe and the new world; explain impact on prestige/power of the monarch and relations with Parliament.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: English privateers: impacts on security, economy, people
Sub_topics.description: Know actions of English privateers and explain impacts on security, economy and the people of England.
Know warfare on the English-Scottish borders c.1500–c.1600 and its impact on border society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of Civil Wars (England, Scotland, Ireland)
Sub_topics.description: Know the nature of the Civil Wars of 1642–1651 across England, Scotland and Ireland; explain types of warfare and how civil war differed from external war.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of Civil Wars on people
Sub_topics.description: Know impacts of the Civil Wars on the people of England, Scotland and Ireland; include displacement, economy, religion and politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Jacobite Wars 1715 and 1745: repression impacts on Scotland
Sub_topics.description: Know the impact on Scotland of repression after the Jacobite Wars 1715 and 1745; explain consequences for culture, society and governance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Seven Years War gains and effects on Britain
Sub_topics.description: Know gains made in the Seven Years War (1756–1763) and explain their effects on Britain (empire, economy, politics).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wars against Revolutionary/Napoleonic France: effects on British society and politics
Sub_topics.description: Know wars against Revolutionary and Napoleonic France and subsequent effects on British society and politics (state power, economy, reform/repression).
Know effects of the Crimean War on Britain (military, political, social; e.g., public opinion, reform) and how war affected government-society relations.
Know effects of the Boer War 1880–1881 on Britain and what it suggests about imperial conflict and society.
Know effects of the Boer War 1899–1902 on Britain (military issues, politics, society) and its significance for debates about empire and preparedness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: World Wars: beginnings of ‘total war’ and impact on lives
Sub_topics.description: Know how WWI and WWII represented beginnings of ‘total war’; explain impacts on people’s lives (mobilisation, labour, rationing, bombing, bereavement).
Know how the world wars increased state power (controls, propaganda, welfare/state planning) and altered state-society relationships.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: World Wars: changing relationship between state and people
Sub_topics.description: Know ways the relationship between the state and the people changed due to the world wars; explain both unity and tensions, expectations of welfare and rights.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cold War and Britain in the 1950s/1960s: impacts and responses
Sub_topics.description: Know impacts and popular responses to Britain’s role in the Cold War in the 1950s and 1960s; explain public attitudes, fear, protest and policy effects.
Know impacts and popular responses to IRA campaigns 1969–1994; explain effects on security policy, civil liberties, public opinion and communities.
Know impacts and popular responses to the Iraq War (2003); explain public protest, political debate and consequences for society/politics.
Know terrorist threats and countermeasures post-2003; explain how security policy affected society, rights and the relationship between government and people.

Topics.Specification_section: The Impact of Empire on Britain 1688–c.1730 (J410/11)
Topics.Topic_name: The Impact of Empire on Britain 1688–c.1730 (J410/11)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Glorious Revolution & Hanoverian succession: significance within British Isles
Sub_topics.description: Know the significance of the Glorious Revolution and the Hanoverian succession for England’s position within the British Isles; explain how dynastic/political change affected power and conflict across the Isles.
Know military campaigns in Ireland 1688–1691 and the settlement that followed; explain impacts on Ireland, power relations and migration/emigration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: England–Scotland relations after 1688 and Jacobite opposition
Sub_topics.description: Know relationship between England and Scotland after 1688 including Jacobite opposition; explain sources of tension and consequences for union/identity.
Know the Massacre of Glencoe (1692) and its significance for Scottish politics, government authority and Jacobite sentiment.
Know the Darien Scheme: aims, failure and consequences; explain how it influenced Scotland’s economic/political position and the move toward union.
Know the Act of Union (1707): reasons and consequences; explain impacts on politics, economy and identity within Britain and empire.
Know the Jacobite Rebellion of 1715 and explain its significance for security, governance and the British state.
Know patterns of emigration (including forced emigration) from the British Isles to the Americas; explain causes and links to imperial expansion and conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War and imperial expansion: changes to British economy
Sub_topics.description: Know the economic impact of war and imperial expansion on Britain; explain key changes to the British economy in 1688–c.1730.
Know the establishment of the Bank of England (1694) and explain significance for finance, war funding and economic development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trade with India/China and East India Company in Kolkata
Sub_topics.description: Know growing trade with India and China, establishment in Kolkata and the role of the East India Company; explain economic and political significance for empire.
Know the lifting of the Royal African Company monopoly (1698) and explain political/economic impact for the slave trade and British ports.
Know the Treaty of Utrecht (1713) and explain its economic/political significance for Britain’s imperial position and trade (including slavery-related concessions).
Know the South Sea Bubble (1719): causes and consequences; explain what it reveals about finance, speculation and empire-linked economics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Importance of North American and Caribbean colonies
Sub_topics.description: Know the economic importance of colonies in North America and the Caribbean and how colonial products/markets shaped Britain’s economy and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins and development of slave-based economy
Sub_topics.description: Know origins and development of the slave-based economy; explain how slavery underpinned imperial wealth and affected Britain and colonies.
Know the emergence of consumerism and its wider political and economic impacts; explain how imperial goods changed consumption, culture and economic patterns.
Know development and role of Bristol as a ‘slave port’ and how the British population was involved in the slave trade through ports and commerce.
Know development and role of Liverpool as a ‘slave port’ and how it linked local economy/society to slavery and empire.
Know development and role of London as a ‘slave port’ and how finance, trade and politics connected to slavery and imperial expansion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Involvement of smaller ports in slave trade
Sub_topics.description: Know involvement of smaller ports in the slave trade; explain how widespread economic participation shaped British society and regional economies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ideas of racial hierarchy and impact on settled minority communities
Sub_topics.description: Know the growth of ideas of a racial hierarchy and how these ideas affected settled minority communities in Britain; explain links between slavery, ideology and racism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to slavery and slave trade (including slave resistance)
Sub_topics.description: Know opposition to slavery and the slave trade, including forms of slave resistance; explain how resistance/activism challenged empire and influenced debate.
Know developing political activism including the role of coffee houses; explain how new public spaces influenced politics, opinion and engagement with imperial issues.
Know the role and importance (including wealth) of the church in England c.1520 and how it shaped community life, politics and economy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religious practice and church-ordinary people relationship
Sub_topics.description: Know religious practice before/during the Reformation and the relationship between the church and ordinary people; explain beliefs, rituals and dependence on the church.
Know the role and impact of Lollards’ ideas as early criticism of the church; explain how such ideas influenced attitudes to reform.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Luther’s ideas and impact in England
Sub_topics.description: Know the role and impact of Luther’s ideas in England; explain routes of spread and how they contributed to criticism and reform pressure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Critics of the English church in the 1530s
Sub_topics.description: Know key criticisms of the English church in the 1530s and why reform ideas gained traction among some groups.
Know popular attitudes towards reform of the church in the 1530s; explain diversity of opinion and why some supported/resisted change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry VIII’s desire to annul first marriage
Sub_topics.description: Know Henry VIII’s desire to annul his first marriage as background context and explain how it connected to political/religious change.
Know key legislation of the Reformation Parliament 1529–1534 and explain how law was used to change church authority and practice.
Know Thomas Cromwell’s role and the Valor Ecclesiasticus; explain why it was carried out and how it enabled dissolution.
Know the Visitation of the Monasteries: purpose, findings/claims and how it contributed to dissolution policy.
Know the process of the Dissolution of the Monasteries and how it unfolded; explain mechanisms of closure, asset seizure and redistribution.
Know the Suppression Act of 1536 and its significance in dissolving smaller monasteries; explain motives and consequences.
Know the Suppression Act of 1539 and its significance in dissolving remaining monasteries; explain consequences for church and society.
Know immediate reactions to Dissolution including support; explain why some groups supported it and benefited.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Immediate reactions to Dissolution: those who took advantage
Sub_topics.description: Know who took advantage of dissolution (land buyers, elites) and explain how redistribution changed local power and economy.
Know those who opposed dissolution and explain reasons (religious, economic, social) and expressions of discontent.
Know effects of dissolution on religious orders and explain what happened to monks/nuns and religious life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effects on ordinary people (especially old and poor)
Sub_topics.description: Know effects of dissolution on the lives of ordinary people, especially the old and poor; explain loss of welfare/support and social consequences.
Know cultural impacts of dissolution (loss of art, libraries, buildings) and explain long-term significance for heritage and communities.
Know the Lincolnshire Rising (1536): causes, events and significance as resistance to religious/economic change.
Know the Pilgrimage of Grace 1536–1537: causes, events, aims and outcomes; explain significance for resistance and government response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religious policy changes under Henry VIII and Edward VI
Sub_topics.description: Know development and changes in religious policy under Henry VIII and Edward VI and how policy shifts affected worship and belief.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changes to church services and prayer books
Sub_topics.description: Know effects of Reformation on religious worship, including changes to church services and prayer books; explain how these altered practice and belief.
Know the issue of the Bible in English and explain its impact on religious understanding, authority and local practice.
Know impact of Reformation on the fabric of churches (images, decoration, layout) and what this reveals about religious change and enforcement.
Know effects of religious change on the clergy and how enforcement and expectations changed their roles and security.
Know how new religious policies were enforced (laws, inspections, punishments) and evaluate effectiveness and resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ordinary people’s responses to religious changes
Sub_topics.description: Know responses of ordinary people to religious changes (acceptance, confusion, resistance) and explain factors shaping reactions.
Know the Prayer Book Rebellion (1549): causes, events and significance as resistance to Protestant reforms.
Know reasons why Charles I called Parliament in 1640 and how financial, political and religious pressures drove this decision.
Know the Long Parliament’s criticisms of Charles I’s Personal Rule financial measures (1629–1640) and why these created opposition.
Know the Long Parliament’s criticisms of Charles I’s religious measures during Personal Rule (1629–1640) and why these increased tensions.
Know how Charles I suppressed criticism during Personal Rule and explain impacts on politics and trust.
Know attacks on Laud and Strafford by Parliament and why they became focal points of opposition; explain significance for escalating conflict.
Know the rebellion in Ireland in 1641 and explain its significance for English politics, fear and the road to civil war.
Know the Grand Remonstrance (1641): content/aim and significance; explain how it intensified divisions.
Know Charles I’s attempt on the Five Members (1642) and explain its significance for breakdown of trust and move to war.
Know the Militia Ordinance (1642) and explain why control of armed forces was central to the constitutional crisis.
Know the Nineteen Propositions (1642) and explain what they reveal about Parliament’s demands and constitutional change.
Know divisions within Parliament 1640–1642 and explain competing aims (religion, settlement with king, limits on monarchy).
Know Parliament’s attempts to reach agreement with Charles I 1646–1647 (Propositions of Newcastle) and why settlement failed/succeeded.
Know Parliament’s reaction to the emergence of new political/religious groups including the Levellers; explain why they were seen as threats/opportunities.
Know Parliament’s reaction to the emergence of Quakers; explain why religious radicalism mattered to settlement and authority.
Know Parliament’s reaction to the emergence of Diggers; explain how social/economic radicalism challenged property and order.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Parliament and Army: Presbyterian vs Independent parties
Sub_topics.description: Know the relationship between Parliament and the Army, including emergence of Presbyterian and Independent parties and how this shaped conflict and settlement options.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Debate about settlement with the King
Sub_topics.description: Know debates about settlement with Charles I and why compromise proved difficult; explain links to religion, power and trust.
Know the execution of Charles I in 1649 and explain significance for monarchy, legitimacy and political radicalisation.
Know the Rump Parliament and declaration of Republic (1649); explain aims and challenges of republican governance.
Know the relationship between Rump Parliament and Cromwell 1649–1653 and why tensions led to constitutional change.
Know the Instrument of Government and its significance as a written constitution; explain what it attempted to achieve.
Know Cromwell’s rule of the Major Generals and explain purpose and impact on local governance, religion and public reaction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Humble Petition and Advice (and Cromwell response)
Sub_topics.description: Know the Humble Petition and Advice and Cromwell’s response; explain significance for attempts at settlement and legitimacy.
Know attempts to reach a settlement September 1658 – April 1660; explain instability after Cromwell and why restoration became likely.
Know restoration of the monarchy including the terms of Restoration c.1660; explain what was agreed and consequences for politics and religion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Immigration and emigration history of the area
Sub_topics.description: Know the history of immigration to and emigration from the specified urban area/site; explain how the site’s physical fabric and documentary evidence reflect population change over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins of migrants and reasons for migration
Sub_topics.description: Know where people migrated from and why (political, economic, social, religious drivers) in the site’s history; explain how evidence at the site reflects these origins and causes.
Know how patterns of migration to the area have changed over time and how these shifts are reflected in the urban environment (buildings, street patterns, institutions, signage).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Settlement patterns of immigrant groups (within area)
Sub_topics.description: Know how and where immigrant groups settled in the area; explain clustering/dispersion, housing and community formation as evidenced in the urban environment.

Know positive and negative responses by the receiving (settled) population; explain how these responses shaped community relations and are reflected in the site (e.g., institutions, memorials, changes of use).
Know positive and negative responses by authorities (local/national where relevant); explain how policy and policing affected migrants and left traces in the urban environment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Housing, welfare and living conditions of immigrants
Sub_topics.description: Know housing, welfare and living conditions of immigrants in the area and how these are evidenced in the urban environment (housing types, density, institutions, reform projects).
Know typical employment and occupations of immigrants in the area and how economic life is reflected in the urban environment (workplaces, markets, dock/port infrastructure, business signage).
Know faith and community organisations created/used by migrants and how these are reflected in buildings, place names, community spaces and commemorations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key local migration events: what and where
Sub_topics.description: Know events of key significance in the immigration history of the area and where these events took place; connect events to specific physical locations and evidence.
Know how key migration-related events are remembered and commemorated (monuments, plaques, museums, street names) and what this reveals about identity and interpretation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economic impact of migration on the area
Sub_topics.description: Know the economic impact of migration on the area and how continued migration has affected and changed local economic life; relate to visible evidence in the site.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Social/cultural/political impact of migration on the area
Sub_topics.description: Know social, cultural and political impact of migration on the area; explain how a current multicultural community developed and how this is reflected in the urban environment.

Topics.Specification_section: Castles: Form and Function c.1000–1750 (J410/12 and J410/13)
Topics.Topic_name: Castles: Form and Function c.1000–1750 (J410/12 and J410/13)

Sub_topics.description: Know the strategic location of Kenilworth Castle and why its position mattered for defence, control and politics across time.
Know the specific geographical location of Kenilworth Castle (regional setting, routes, terrain) and how geography influenced function.
Know the specific physical location of Kenilworth Castle within its immediate landscape (elevation, water/defensive features) and how this supported defence/status.

Know the types of evidence historians use for the castle’s location, e.g. maps from medieval to modern times and drawings in local histories; understand how such evidence supports conclusions about strategic/physical siting.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Motte and bailey layout (features and meaning)
Sub_topics.description: Know key features of motte and bailey layouts and what they reveal about Norman conquest/early castle function; relate to Kenilworth where relevant.
Know why stone towers were built/modified and what they reveal about military technology, permanence and elite power.
Know defensive features (walls, ditches, gatehouses, water defences) and how/why they were installed or altered; connect changes to national context and threats.
Know the great hall’s role and what it reveals about lordship, hospitality, administration and display/intimidation.
Know the role of a causeway/access routes in castle layout and what it reveals about defence and managing movement/authority.
Know when and why features were removed including the slighting of Kenilworth Castle; explain what slighting reveals about civil war politics and shifting power.

Know the range of evidence used to study appearance/layout changes (contracts, architectural plans, contemporary drawings, aerial photographs) and how these sources support reconstructions of the site over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Castle as means of conquest (Norman period)
Sub_topics.description: Know how Kenilworth/castles functioned as means of conquest particularly in the Norman period; explain how castles enabled control over territory and population.
Know how Kenilworth/castles functioned as means of baronial and/or royal power; explain intimidation, lordship, military leverage and political symbolism.
Know how Kenilworth/castles functioned as centres of administration and justice (tax, courts, governance, prison roles) and how this reflects state development.
Know how castles functioned as elite residences combining comfort with display; explain how domestic features reflect changing priorities and technology.
Know examples of evidence used by historians for day-to-day function (e.g., royal licences, newspaper articles) and how to use them to infer function and change over time.
Know the De Clintons as castle owners and what their ownership reveals about Norman/medieval power and castle development.
Know Simon de Montfort’s association with Kenilworth and explain significance within baronial conflict and political history.
Know the Lancaster connection to Kenilworth and what it indicates about royal/baronial power and castle use.
Know John of Gaunt’s link to Kenilworth and explain significance for elite residence, power and patronage.
Know Tudor connections to Kenilworth and how Tudor politics/court culture shaped castle function and display.
Know the Dudleys’ association with Kenilworth and explain significance for Elizabethan politics, patronage and display.
Know the Stuarts’ association with Kenilworth and explain significance for civil war context, property and power.
Know the Hydes’ association with Kenilworth and explain what later ownership reveals about the site’s changing role/status.
Know roles of people who made the castle function (e.g., blacksmiths, cooks and other staff); explain what their work reveals about daily life, economy and hierarchy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for life in the castle (bills/accounts/inventories)
Sub_topics.description: Know evidence types for life in the castle (bills and accounts, inventories) and how historians use them to reconstruct consumption, staffing, status and daily routines.
Know Kenilworth Castle’s connections to baronial and other rebellions and explain why the site was significant in conflict and power struggles.
Know any specified connections between Kenilworth and border warfare and explain how castles could be involved in national defence and regional conflict.
Know Kenilworth Castle’s connections to civil war sieges and explain how siege warfare affected the site’s fabric and political significance.
